dc:title: É dingir-dingir(-dingir), « Sanctum des ancêtres divinisés », dans les textes d’Ébla
dc:creator: Jacopo Pasquali
bibo:note: In this study, Pasquali examines passages in the Ebla documents pertaining to a structure known as e₂-dingir-dingir(-dingir). The author begins by evaluating the current interpretation of this term as referring to a temple dedicated to the Ebla pantheon. However, despite being dedicated to various deities, there is no mention of a cult image associated with this temple in the sources. Regarding the mi-sa-ga-ti-im rite, the author highlights that the god Hadda plays no role in the transmission of royalty; this duty is assigned to KUra, Barama (his spouse), and the deified ancestors. Drawing parallels with Emar and Ugarit, the author suggests that the worship of deities in the 'temple of the gods' could be linked to the deified ancestors of the ruling family.

dc:title: Testi lessicali bilingui della Biblioteca L.2769. Parte I: Traslitterazione dei testi e ricostruzione del VE
dc:creator: Giovanni Pettinato
bibo:note: In this volume Giovanni Pettinato offers the first edition of the most important bilingual lexical documents found at Ebla. In the introduction the author describe the main sources: the volume contains 114 bilingual texts (mostly fragmentary), of which 60 documents plus 12 fragments are classified as sources of the bilingual vocabulary. Furthermore, 39 documents plus 3 fragments belong to the group of the so-called ‘estratti del vocabolario’ (EV). MEE 4 also includes the edition of the main manuscript (source) of the unilingual eš-bar-kin₅ acrographic series, which constitutes the backbone of the bilingual vocabulary. The last document (MEE 4, 116) has been recognized as a Bilingual List of Animals. Volume II has not been published. The identification of the sources (i.e., manuscripts) of the VE has since been substantially revised.

dc:title: Eblaita dgú-ša-ra-tum = ugaritico kṯrt
dc:creator: Jacopo Pasquali
bibo:note: In this note Pasquali offers a new interpretation of the divine name dingirgu₂-ša-ra-tum. The same author had previously identified the term as a plural of dingirga-ša-lu, from gašāru, “to be strong” (see Pasquali 2005, 134-135). Pasquali offers here a new interpretation, suggesting that although the term refers to a group of seven female deities, it connects to Ugr. kṯrt, Akk. šassūrum, also attested in Mari pantheon as kuwašūratum / kūša[rātum]. The root is √kṯr, 'skilful', which is also the name of the god of technology (DUL3, s.v. √kṯr (I, III), 467-468). Their seven statues had face, hands and feet covered in silver. Each held a bronze gu₂-a-tum. On this tool, see Pasquali, 'gú-a-tum' (2022).

dc:title: Sacrifices, Divination and Ritual Consumption of Meat. The uzu Deliveries to the King of Ebla and the šu-mu-nígin of God NIdabal of Luban
dc:creator: Maria Vittoria Tonietti
bibo:booktitle: Libiamo ne’ lieti calici. Ancient Near Eastern Studies Presented to Lucio Milano on the Occasion of his 65th Birthday by Pupils, Colleagues and Friends
bibo:note: In this paper, Tonietti focuses on the ritual consumption of meat. Although meat (uzu) rarely appears in the administrative record, sheep offerings (udu nidba₂) are widely attested especially in cultic contexts. After an overview of the documented records of meat deliveries, Tonietti investigates those concerning NIdabal's festival offering a new interpretation of the expression 'šu mu-tak₄ uzu aš₂-aš NIdabal'. According to her reconstruction, the members of the elite received the meat which was by (aš₂-da) NIdabal, i.e., of the sheep sacrificed in Luban for the god's šu-mu-nigin₂.
